author: Simon Harris
title: Government pushes ahead with new crackdown on Tube and rail strikes | London
text:
New laws to make it harder for the unions to cripple London's transport network came a step closer today.
Credit: PA The government published its Trade Union Bill which proposes tough new rules over strike ballots.
But the legislation was immediately condemned by union leaders and senior Labour politicians.
Credit: PA The changes will impose a minimum 50% turnout before a strike can be called.
The government is interdicting an extra hurdle in key public services including health, education, fire and transport. Industrial action must be backed by at least 40% of those entitled to vote.
Credit: PA We know that these brutal new anti-union laws are specifically targeted at our members in the transport sector who have shown in recent months that they have the guts to stand up and fight for jobs, pay, services and safety.
– Mick Cash, RMT General Secretary London Underground workers are due to stage a second strike over pay and new night shifts on August. Talks between the two sides were continuing at Acas today.
I have been calling for these reforms in London for many years as they will prevent the type of wildcat strike action that is triggered by a tiny minority of workers, yet punishes the vast majority who still wish to work and holds millions of Londoners to ransom.
It is not about abolishing people’s right to withdraw labour, it is actually about protecting hardworking people on those occasions when the vast majority clearly want to continue to work, and want to help contribute to the storming success story that is London.
We should also look at these changes in the context of the massive investment being made in our transport system, which is delivering more trains and buses, delivering better services and creating thousands more jobs.
– Boris Johnson, Mayor of London Last updated Wed 15 Jul 2015 Travel London
